text.p: The newspaper of America's Jewish immigrants did its job so well that it practically put itself out of business.
The Forward, which as one admirer put it taught Yiddish-speaking immigrants from Eastern Europe how to use a handkerchief and how to use a vote, celebrated its 100th birthday on Sunday.

But the future of the paper that exhorted "Workers of the World Unite" on its masthead is uncertain, and the main hope of keeping its proud tradition alive lies with an English edition run by a man who used to work at the Wall Street Journal.

"There really is no more distinguished newspaper in this city and country than the Forward," said David Remnick, a writer with the New Yorker magazine. "No paper has had a bigger heart, no paper has been more informative and literary and brave."
The Forverts, as it's known in Yiddish, was started in 1897 by a group of peddlers, tailors and cigar makers who gave a day's pay to start a paper to trumpet the socialist dream.

It debuted as a daily and reached its peak circulation of 275,000 in the 1930s. It claims to be the first American newspaper to have a national circulation but its readership and influence began to erode in the post-war period as more and more American Jews achieved the Forward's dream and assimilated.
PAPER'S WRITER WINS NOBEL

"It's the only newspaper in history to have won the Nobel Prize beacuse Isaac Bashevis Singer got the Nobel for stories that were written for the Forward," said Seth Lipsky, a veteran of the Wall Street Journal editorial board and now the editor of the seven-year-old English Forward.

Besides Singer's writing, the Forward was famous for its Bintel Brief column, a letters-to-the-editor advice column. Poor Jewish women on the Lower East Side wrote the column asking for someone to adopt their children because they were going hungry.

But not all of the correspondence was doom and gloom. A letter in 1908 from a man who was reluctant to marry his girlfriend because she had a dimple asked if it was true that people who have a dimple on their chin lose their first spouse. The editors replied: "The tragedy is not that the girl has a dimple on her chin but that some people have a screw loose in their heads."

The founding editor of the paper was Abraham Cahan, a Russian-born novelist and revolutionary who quit during the first year because he didn't want the Forward to be a mouthpiece for socialist ideology. Cahan came back four years later and ran the paper until he died 50 years later.

"Very few English language dailies today have the personal stamp of the editor the way the Forverts did," said Zachary Baker, head librarian of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, where all 100 years of the Yiddish Forward are available on microfilm.
"Abe Cahan was opinionated, cantankerous and prone to feuds. But at heart he was a strong believer in the American way and the Jewish people."
PAPER HAD DETRACTORS

Of course the Forward has its detractors. Intellectuals grumbled about it corrupting Yiddish with Americanisms. Religious Jews wouldn't touch it because it was secular. And Yiddish-speaking communists had their own daily, the Freiheit.
The Forward's influence in the first half of the 20th century was undeniable. In 1914 the paper helped make Meyer London the first socialist elected to Congress.

And over the years it broke a number of spectacular stories, including the introduction of slave labour in the Soviet Union. During the Second World War, the Forward played a role in mobilising the American public against the Nazis.

"As much as any paper in the world, and more than most, the Forward broke the story of the Holocaust," Lipsky says proudly. Long before other papers, the paper printed stories about Jewish communities in Eastern Europe disappearing.
The English-language Forward has continued its tradition of publishing original literary works, serializing the Holocaust comic strip Maus and Phillip Roth's novel "Operation Shylock."

And like the old Yiddish Forverts, it aggressively covers what it considers anti-semitism. The English edition has also been hawkish on foreign affairs. In 1991 it became the first U.S. paper to call for a declaration of war against Iraq.

To some critics, however, the paper has at times allowed its ideology to creep into its news pages. "I think it's a first rate piece of work," says New York Times columnist A.M. Rosenthal, "but I've been noticing that some of its news stories are heavily editorialised. It's not overwhelming at this point but I can smell those things in any paper."

After seven years of publication, the English Forward's circulation is about 24,000 and, according to one editor, the paper is losing $1 million a year. The Yiddish edition has a weekly readership of 10,000. Both papers are subsidised by the sale a few years ago of a radio station the paper owned.
Despite the yearly losses, Lipsky says he plans to eventually make it a daily. That may sound like a pipe dream, but at least one newspaper analyst believes Lipsky has a shot.

"A lean and mean Jewish Forward can survive on circulation revenue alone if it can get up to a critical mass of somewhere between 50,000 and a 100,000 copies a day," said Porter Bibb of the Ladenburg, Thallman & Co, an investment banking firm.

"An awful lot of Jews in New York would buy a daily Jewish Forward because it could provide a sense of identity for the hundreds of thousands of affluent Jews in New York who have lost a connection with their faith."
